title: 109_hr6160
content: The Act may be cited as the "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" and focuses on enhancing Border Patrol agents. The "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" aims to address recruitment and retention challenges faced by the United States Border Patrol. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a plan within six months to improve recruitment and retention of agents with appropriate skills. The plan should include strategies for recruitment authority and other important factors. The plan to improve recruitment and retention of Border Patrol agents includes strategies for recruitment authority, retention authority, assessing pay levels' impact, and evaluating opportunities for agents to transfer between duty stations. SEC. 3. RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION BONUSES FOR BORDER PATROL AGENT ENHANCEMENT. SEC. 3. RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION BONUSES FOR BORDER PATROL AGENT ENHANCEMENT. Chapter 97 of title 5, United States Code, amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to pay recruitment bonuses to individuals for Border Patrol agents. Bonus amount determined by the Secretary, not to exceed 25 percent of the annual rate of basic pay. A bonus under this subsection is paid as a lump-sum and is not part of basic pay. Payment is contingent on entering a service agreement with the United States Border Patrol, specifying the service period and conditions for termination. The bonus cannot be used to recruit individuals. The section outlines restrictions on paying bonuses for certain positions appointed by the President or in the Senior Executive Service. The authority to pay bonuses will end five years after enactment. Additionally, retention bonuses for Border Patrol Agents are discussed. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay a retention bonus to Border Patrol agents under certain conditions, including entering into a service agreement. The agreement specifies the required service period and conditions for termination. The Secretary of Homeland Security can pay a retention bonus to Border Patrol agents, not exceeding 25% of their annual basic pay. The bonus is a lump-sum payment and cannot be part of basic pay. It cannot be based on the same service period as a recruitment bonus and the authority to grant bonuses will expire five years after enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to appoint annuitants to positions within the United States Border Patrol to address challenges. Appointed annuitants are not subject to certain provisions and are not considered employees for specific purposes. The Secretary of Homeland Security can appoint annuitants to Border Patrol positions for up to five years after this subsection's enactment. Appointed annuitants are excluded from certain provisions for up to five years of service and cannot displace existing Border Patrol employees. The House of Representatives passed the Border Patrol agent enhancement on September 26, 2006.
